There is evidence to suggest that some of Augustine's former colleagues and associates eventually accepted his new faith. For example, after his conversion, Augustine maintained a correspondence with his old friend and fellow philosopher, Alypius of Thagaste.

In one of his letters to Alypius, Augustine thanked him for his support and encouragement during the difficult transition period after his conversion. This suggests that Alypius may have accepted Augustine's new faith and remained a friend and supporter.

It is important to note, however, that many of Augustine's former colleagues remained skeptical or outright hostile to his new Christian beliefs. Some of them continued to criticize him and his ideas throughout his life.

Despite this opposition, Augustine remained committed to his faith and continued to defend it through his writing and teachings. His influence on Christianity and Western philosophy is still felt today, and his works continue to be studied and discussed by scholars around the world.
